newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU agrees to ban calves crates.
newsitem.headline: EU agrees to ban calves crates.

text.p: European Union farm ministers agreed on Tuesday to ban by 2006 the use of cramped crates for rearing calves over two months old and to improve their diet, EU officials said.
New-style crates, which have already been condemned by animal welfare groups as cruel, will be banned from January 1998 and old crates they were meant to replace phased out over eight years.
"It's been agreed," an official said, noting Italy voted against and Spain abstained.

Agreement was reached after France, the main user of veal crates, obtained a pledge that the European Commission would examine any trade distortion caused by a new early marketing subsidy scheme for calves.
A Commission report said calves suffer severe stress and health problems when they are confined in individual crates and fed on a milky diet lacking iron in order to produce white meat.
Calves will now also be given hay and water while those kept in group pens will be given more room to move. Farmers will be given EU aid to adjust to the new production rules.
